Adjacency, Encino.

In one of Lev Kuleshovâ€™s film editing experiments, shots of an actorâ€™s expressionless face were sequentially coupled with different images to induce different emotional reactions from viewers. First, the shot of the face was paired with an image of a hot bowl of soup, and the audience, upon viewing the sequence, assumed that he was hungry. Next, that same shot of the expressionless face was paired with a shot of a small child lying dead in a casket. Despite the fact that it was the same shot of the actorâ€™s face, the viewers now felt he was sad and in emotional pain. This montage technique is known as the Kuleshov Effect. Our perception of a given image is affected by the context of images that it is shown with. The effect also shows just how easily our visual perception can be manipulated and altered with, evidently, predictable results.

Contemporary life exposes us to a barrage of sensorial stimuli on a daily basis, asking us to filter out unwanted information and organize what our perceptions intertwine with â€” or at least, we attempt to do so. We now live in the too-much-information age and, to some extent, we are all trying to strip down the toxic levels of mostly visual and auditory distraction that are directed at our individual and collective attention. Although we perk up at things we are interested in, as we try to curate and organize what is pertinent to our sense of need and self, ultimately, we are still ingesting all of it like a dry sponge thrown into a bucket of water. Our daily incoming stream of sensory input sets up an adjacency of images, sounds, colors, form, and texture that, much like the Kuleshov Effect, alter and affect a particular moment with bookends of other moments as they lock into our consciousness. Directing your attention towards something, even for the briefest of moments, will be dogged and shadowed by collateral stimuli caught in the same linear path of consumption.

Although Additional Parking purports to be a visually non-hierarchical look at the city of Los Angeles, viewers will, without effort, still bring their interests, needs, and desires to bear on the piece. Viewers passively impose their own particular kind of order and meaning upon what they see, while the video attempts to disrupt their habits of visual consumption by, in turn, amplifying it. Inevitably, a viewer may recognize a location in one of the shots, another may find a compositional counterpoint to cast an anchor upon or simply have a memory triggered by an object or image they see. A wandering train of thought, whilst still taking in the videoâ€™s flow of imagery, will only be punctuated again and again by an interminable stream of associations. Additional Parking is structurally haunted by its own flow of imagery and by the ghosts that viewers bring along. This all too awkward dance with distraction is a soft fact of contemporary existence. The shadows cast in the videoâ€™s adjacency of imagery produces any number of associative meanings, and coupled with the viewerâ€™s particular interests, we can see a larger, almost ethereal composition emerging and percolating itself into existence. Itâ€™s a mess that someone, thankfully, never seems to clean up.

Los Angeles has many chronic urban problems but none are as pressing and in urgent need of resolution as the cityâ€™s increasing homeless population. Depending on your sources, there are estimates that the unsheltered population is roughly 41,000 citywide and 66,000 in the entire county of Los Angeles.22 These numbers are conservative since it is hard to estimate how many people are also living in cars, vans, and campers throughout the city, particularly in the outer suburban and industrial areas. The way Los Angeles deals with its homeless population is a complicated and persistent issue that is only exaggerated by the economic disparities in the city. In contrast to the tens of thousands of people living on the streets all over the city, Jeff Bezos purchased a 9-acre estate for a reported 165 million dollars.23

A common misconception about the homeless population of Los Angeles is that most of them drifted into the city from elsewhere, attracted by the weather and an abundance of open space. This simply isnâ€™t true and, unlike Mr. Bezos, 80% of people who end up in the streets of Los Angeles have resided in the city for five or more years,24 and 65% have been residents for 20 years or more.25 This is a home-grown issue and one that formulates because of specific socioeconomic difficulties that are unique to the city and its ever-growing population. Although there are often overlapping causes for homelessness, the main one remains economic hardship followed closely by mental health problems, substance abuse, and the long lasting effects of systemic racism.26

If you live in Los Angeles itâ€™s hard to sidestep the issue and pretend itâ€™s not there. If you donâ€™t breathe the rarified air of communities like Malibu, the Palisades, Brentwood, Bel Air, Holmby Hills, or Beverly Hills, itâ€™s hard to imagine a day passing in which poverty in the city is not openly displayed and the ballooning population of unsheltered people living on the streets arenâ€™t encountered. Given that the average rent in the city is now sneaking up to half the average income, most citizens are a few paychecks away from losing the tenuous foothold they have in the housing market. Homelessness in Los Angeles is a civic embarrassment considering the staggering levels of wealth and affluence that are on display in this city. For most of us who live in Los Angeles, at least those with some level of empathy, there is an incredible palpable sadness to all of this. Poverty and misery have become a distinct part of the cityâ€™s gritty character.

Once visitors and tourists in Los Angeles have taken a selfie in front of the Hollywood sign, given up on their Map to the Stars and glimpsed at the Pacific Ocean, the only thing left for them to do is to aimlessly drive around the city searching for something else to place in front of their cameras. What most outsiders donâ€™t realize is that Los Angeles is a working town. People move here to make money and have the life squeezed out of them. They either die here, or move back to where they came from to die.

Unlike San Francisco, New York, and other great American cities, Los Angeles is not a tourist town, and other than Disneyland â€” which is actually in Anaheim â€” itâ€™s unclear why anyone would want to come here as a tourist. While tootling around looking for an elusive opportunity to snap a shot of Keanu Reeves on his motorcycle, these same tourists may notice mysterious yellow and black signs that direct film and television crews to temporary production sites. These ambiguously named productions employ a deliberate language of misdirections, designed to thwart the efforts of obsessive fans from showing up to the production site. Unaware of these facts, visitors may mistake the signs as the urban poetry of a local lunatic.

Translated from Spanish to English, â€œtienditaâ€ means little shop. Itâ€™s somewhat common to encounter mobile stores in rural and outlying areas beyond the city. My first visit to one was up in the Santa Clarita Valley, in the town of Val Verde, a small community once known as the â€œBlack Palm Springs.â€ With no stores of its own, residents have the choice to drive to a neighboring town for supplies, or stop by one of these small stores on wheels. In isolated towns like Val Verde, shipping in basic goods and food makes sense.

These trucks are all over the city and are always found in densely populated neighborhoods, home to large working-class immigrants. They can be found in the Valley, Glendale, Hollywood, South Central, and Long Beach. There is no shortage of grocery stores in these areas, there are bodegas and shops where one can pick up practically anything sold in these mobile stores. So why shop at these tienditas? They can offer lower prices because no rent is being paid. Also, their success is attributable to access and how conveniently close they are, directly catering to the income level and population density of the areas they serve. Itâ€™s unlikely youâ€™ll find mobile tienditas in the Trousdale Estates or in Brentwood.

Improvised Living, Rose Hills.

Just about three miles from downtown Los Angeles is Rose Hills. It hovers above Happy Valley and is a small part of the general Lincoln Heights area. To drive around these hills is to step back into a Los Angeles that existed almost a hundred years ago. It is sparsely populated with old and dilapidated housing. I would describe most of these living arrangements as improvised and make-shift. Many of the paved roads are so small they wouldnâ€™t be able to accommodate the width of a large vehicle such as a fire truck. Delivering packages must be a nightmare for parcel services and postal workers. Some roads, particularly the ones on steep inclines, are unpaved and unmaintained. One of the most entertaining drives Iâ€™ve ever taken was up Telluride Street heading towards Amethyst Street. It is not for the faint of heart and a 4WD car is advisable. You can somewhat recreate the experience by clicking your way up the hilly dirt road using Google Street View.

Shown here is the home of a couple of artist friends of mine. They purchased the land very cheaply because there were no direct paved roads to the lot, and it is located on a pretty steep incline. After carving out a level area and installing a septic tank, they somehow managed to lower a caravan down to the lot and hooked it up with solar panels â€” water gets delivered to a large holding container they also had installed. I think the plan is to eventually build something small and affordable, but for now theyâ€™ve improvised and live debt-free without much overhead. What theyâ€™ve done is admirable, it reminds me of one of the reasons I moved here. Los Angeles was once a cheap place for artists to live, a place where you could figure out a situation for yourself and get to work.

Los Angeles is littered with an incredible number of airports and landing stations that support commercial flights, aerospace development, the military, and the Los Angeles Police departmentâ€™s air support division, as well as recreational enthusiasts. In Los Angeles, one of the first things one needs to acclimatize to is the alarming number of helicopters flying about. Some of them are commercial flights, some are from news stations or paparazzi, but the ones you really notice are the LAPD helicopters. When engaged in a pursuit, their helicopters fly low and loud while circling their prey. If you live in lower-income areas, having one looping around your neighborhood for hours on end can be both common and excruciating.

Helicopter sightings are a daily occurrence in Los Angeles. At some point, it simply becomes a part of the city. One quickly learns to distinguish between the coloring of civilian and police helicopters, even the way they fly can be telling. News helicopters tend to station themselves above whatever it is they want to film, the police
